newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Justice Dept. cracks down on copyright fraud.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Justice Dept. cracks down on copyright fraud.

text.p: The Justice Department and the FBI announced on Thursday the first results of a nationwide crackdown, dubbed "Operation Counter Copy," against trademark and copyright fraud involving counterfeit products.
The two agencies said 35 indictments were returned last month in various cities for copyright or trademark infringement as part of the crackdown that began in October 1996.

"Operation Counter Copy sends a strong message to major counterfeiters and copyright pirates all across the U.S. -- you will be investigated, prosecuted and, if convicted, sent to jail," Attorney General Janet Reno said in a statement.

The cases included counterfeit products appearing to be made by such companies as NIKE, Calvin Klein, Guess and other makers of brand-named goods. Copyright cases involved pirated video and audio cassettes and computer software.
Department officials said various domestic industries sustain about $2.8 billion in estimated losses a year as a result of copyright infringement and counterfeit products in the United States.
They said industry groups estimated that piracy outside the United States totalled $20 billion in 1996.
